tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving shear flow in a stiffened cross-section. It requires understanding of shear flow concepts and applying them to the given geometry, involving multiple steps to calculate the shear flow in each web. It also integrates concepts of structural mechanics and geometry.

answer_validation.reasoning: The cross-section is a single-cell closed thin-walled rectangle with uniform wall thickness. Under a pure torque T, the shear flow q is constant around the perimeter: T = 2 A q, where A is the enclosed area. The rectangle has width 500 mm and height 200 mm, so A = 0.5 m \times 0.2 m = 0.1 m^2. The applied torque is T = 10 kNm = 10 000 N m. Thus q = T / (2A) = 10 000 / (0.2) = 50 000 N/m = 50 kN/m. Since the shear flow is the same in all four webs, q_{AB} = q_{BC} = q_{CD} = q_{DA} = 50 kN/m, which corresponds to option D.

step_by_step: Identify that the four webs form a single closed thin-walled cell (rectangular box) with uniform thickness, subjected only to a twisting moment (torque).
Recall that for a single-cell thin-walled closed section with constant shear flow q, the torque is given by T = 2 A q, where A is the area enclosed by the median line of the wall.
Read dimensions from the figure: horizontal distance BC (and AD) is 500 mm = 0.5 m; vertical distance CD (and AB) is 200 mm = 0.2 m. Hence the enclosed area is A = 0.5 \times 0.2 = 0.1 m^2.
Convert the applied torque: T = 10 kNm = 10 000 N m.
Solve for shear flow: q = T / (2A) = 10 000 / (2 \times 0.1) = 10 000 / 0.2 = 50 000 N/m = 50 kN/m.
Because the section is a single cell with uniform thickness, the shear flow magnitude is the same in all four webs: q_{AB} = q_{BC} = q_{CD} = q_{DA} = 50 kN/m.

topic.name: Thin-walled closed section torsion and shear flow
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures -> Bending, shear and torsion of thin-walled members

concepts.name: Shear flow in single-cell closed sections
Idealization of stiffened sections into booms and shear panels

essential: Basic concept of torque and twisting of beams
Definition and units of shear flow
Area calculation for simple geometric shapes
helpful: Understanding of structural idealization using booms and webs
Membrane analogy for torsion of thin-walled sections

Main Concept: requires: Thin-walled closed section torsion theory
requires: Ability to compute enclosed area of cross-section
enables: Analysis of multi-cell wing and fuselage box beams
enables: Design of efficient torsion-resistant aircraft structures

difficulty_factors: Requires remembering the specific formula T = 2 A q for single-cell closed sections
Students may be distracted by given boom areas and web thickness, which are not needed for this torque-only question

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a thin-walled closed section of single cell with uniform shear flow q, the torque is given by T = 2 A q, where A is the area enclosed by the median line of the wall.

video_references.topic_covered: Shear flow in thin-walled closed sections and derivation of T = 2Aq

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Recognize single-cell closed section -> Use T = 2 A q -> Compute area from dimensions -> Convert torque units -> Solve for q -> Assign same q to all webs
key_insights: For a single-cell closed thin-walled section with uniform thickness, the shear flow due to pure torque is constant around the perimeter.
Boom areas and web thickness are irrelevant for finding q when only torque is applied and warping is free.

formulas_principles.name: Torque-shear flow relation for single-cell closed section
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to thin-walled single-cell closed sections with uniform shear flow under pure torque
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation used to compute shear flow from applied torque and enclosed area

formulas_principles.name: Area of rectangle
formulas_principles.conditions: Rectangle with width b and height h
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute the enclosed area of the rectangular cell

formulas_principles.name: Shear flow from torque and area
formulas_principles.conditions: Derived from T = 2 A q for single-cell closed section
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly yields the numerical value of shear flow

industry_examples: Design of aircraft wing and fuselage box sections where torque from aerodynamic loads is carried mainly by shear flow in thin skins and webs
Helicopter tail boom design, which often uses thin-walled closed sections to resist torsion from tail rotor thrust
specific_systems: Transport aircraft wing torsion box between front and rear spars
Pressurized fuselage frames and skins forming closed cells
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate estimation of shear flow in thin-walled closed sections is essential to size skins and webs against shear yielding and buckling under torsional loads.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using open-section torsion formulas (e.g., summing bt^3 terms) instead of the closed-section relation T = 2 A q.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They may not clearly distinguish between open and closed thin-walled sections under torsion.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: First classify the section: if it forms a closed loop, recall that torque is carried by shear flow around the cell and use T = 2 A q.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to completely wrong magnitude of shear flow and misunderstanding of load paths.

common_mistakes.mistake: Trying to use given boom areas and web thickness to compute shear stress directly, instead of first finding shear flow from torque.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They assume every given number must be used and overcomplicate the problem.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Ask what quantity is requested (shear flow, not stress) and recall that for torque-only in a single cell, q depends only on T and A.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes time and may lead to incorrect answers if an inconsistent method is used.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the wrong area, such as the sum of web areas (perimeter times thickness) instead of the enclosed cell area.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between cross-sectional area and enclosed area for torsion.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that in T = 2 A q, A is the area enclosed by the median line of the wall, not the material area of the walls.
common_mistakes.consequence: Produces shear flow off by a large factor.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: “Torque Twists the Tube: Two times Area times q”
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering T = 2 A q for single-cell closed sections
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever dealing with torsion of thin-walled closed tubes or box beams.

flashcards.front: For a thin-walled single-cell closed section under pure torque, what is the relation between torque T, enclosed area A, and shear flow q?
flashcards.back: The relation is $T = 2 A q$, where A is the area enclosed by the median line of the wall and q is the (constant) shear flow.

flashcards.front: In a rectangular thin-walled box beam under pure torque, is the shear flow the same in all walls? Why?
flashcards.back: Yes. For a single-cell closed section with uniform thickness and pure torque, equilibrium and compatibility require a constant shear flow around the entire perimeter.

flashcards.front: A rectangular thin-walled box (0.4 m by 0.3 m) carries a torque of 12 kNm. Find the shear flow q.
In T = 2 A q for thin-walled closed sections, what does A represent and what does it NOT represent?
flashcards.back: A is the area enclosed by the median line of the wall (cell area). It is NOT the sum of wall cross-sectional areas (thickness times length).

real_world_context.application: Aircraft wing torsion box under aerodynamic pitching moments
real_world_context.industry_example: A transport aircraft wing box with a 3 m by 0.5 m cell carrying several hundred kNm of torque; engineers compute shear flow to size the upper and lower skins and spar webs.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating shear flow can lead to skin buckling or failure, compromising structural integrity and safety.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a single-cell closed-section torsion problem; immediately write T = 2 A q, compute the rectangular area from the figure, and solve for q. Ignore extra data like boom areas unless the question explicitly asks for stress.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, note that for a single-cell box under torque, all webs usually carry equal shear flow, so prefer options where all four values are equal.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within about 1–2 minutes; do not overcomplicate by trying to compute stresses or using boom areas.

search_keywords: Megson closed section beams shear flow
GATE AE structures torsion thin walled

alternative_methods.name: Membrane analogy for torsion
alternative_methods.description: Model the thin-walled closed section as an equivalent membrane under pressure; the shear flow corresponds to membrane tension, and torque corresponds to the resultant moment of this tension.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives physical insight into why shear flow is constant and why T = 2 A q. Cons: More conceptual and less direct for quick numerical problems.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful for deeper understanding or when deriving formulas for more complex multi-cell sections.

connections_to_other_subjects.Aerodynamics: Wing torsion due to aerodynamic pitching moments must be carried by the wing box; understanding shear flow links structural design with aerodynamic load predictions.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Torsional stiffness of wings affects aeroelastic phenomena like divergence and flutter.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Structural flexibility, including torsion of control surfaces, influences control effectiveness and must be modeled in dynamic systems.

deeper_dive_topics: Shear flow distribution in multi-cell closed sections and compatibility of twist
Effect of non-uniform wall thickness on shear flow
Warping restraint and torsional stiffness of thin-walled beams
Shear center and center of twist in open and closed sections

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Bending, shear and torsion of thin-walled members; shear flow in open and closed sections
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Question nicely tests core formula for torsion of thin-walled closed sections without algebraic complexity, appropriate for 2-mark MCQ.

rag_quality.notes: RAG chunks mainly discussed torsion of strips and general closed-section beam behavior, reinforcing concepts of shear flow and torsion but did not directly present the simple T = 2 A q relation for a single-cell rectangle. Core solution relied on standard thin-walled torsion theory from model knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Ask for shear stress in each web by dividing shear flow by thickness, using the same geometry.
Extend to a two-cell box with an internal web and ask for different shear flows in each cell using compatibility of twist.
Include an additional vertical shear force and ask for combined shear flow due to torque and shear.
Ask for angle of twist per unit length using torsional stiffness of the thin-walled closed section.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The stiffened cross-section of a long slender uniform structural member is idealized as shown in the figure below. The lumped areas at A, B, C and D have equal cross-sectional area of 3 cm². The webs AB, BC, CD and DA are each 5 mm thick. The structural member is subjected to a twisting moment of 10 kNm. The magnitudes of the shear flow in the webs, qAB, qBC, qCD, and qDA in kN/m are, respectively
